articles.headline: The Far-Right Christian Quest for Power: ‘We Are Seeing Them Emboldened’
articles.snippet: Political candidates on the fringe mix religious fervor with conspiracy theories, even calling for the end of the separation of church and state.
articles.abstract: Political candidates on the fringe mix religious fervor with conspiracy theories, even calling for the end of the separation of church and state.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Moves to End $44 Billion Deal to Buy Twitter
articles.snippet: In a regulatory filing on Friday, Mr. Musk said Twitter was in “material breach” of the acquisition agreement.
articles.abstract: In a regulatory filing on Friday, Mr. Musk said Twitter was in “material breach” of the acquisition agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Less than three months ago, Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, struck a blockbuster $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. He proclaimed that the company had “tremendous potential.”
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Columbia Loses Its No. 2 Spot in the U.S. News Rankings
articles.snippet: U.S. News & World Report announced that it had “unranked” the Ivy League university after being unable to verify its data.
articles.abstract: U.S. News & World Report announced that it had “unranked” the Ivy League university after being unable to verify its data.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is the equivalent of “disbarred” or “defrocked” in the world of college rankings?

articles.headline: Companies’ Climate Promises Face a Wild Card: Farmers
articles.snippet: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.
articles.abstract: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Driving rain pelted the windows of “the Tower,” a second-story glass enclosure in Ray Gaesser’s home that provides a view for miles of the gentle, rolling fields around Corning, Iowa. Inside, away from the elements, Mr. Gaesser pondered what the coming year might bring for farmers.

articles.headline: Ukraine and the Contest of Global Stamina
articles.snippet: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
articles.abstract: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another day, another weapons shipment: On Friday, the Pentagon announced a new transfer of precision-guided shells and multiple rocket launchers to Ukraine, the latest armaments heading east. But will there come a day when that system begins to slow?
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Nice-Guy Lawyer for America’s Tabloid Villains
articles.snippet: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.
articles.abstract: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even when there are few cameras around, Arthur L. Aidala, 54, is camera-ready, dressed in a light-blue pinstripe suit with a purple pocket square and tie on a sunny June day. He’s a lawyer who welcomes press attention, but on this particular day he was worried about the way it can make a difficult job harder.

articles.headline: ‘I Felt Trapped’: Sexual Abuse of Teens in the Military’s J.R.O.T.C. Program
articles.snippet: Former students say military veterans who led J.R.O.T.C. classes in U.S. high schools fashioned themselves as mentors, then used their power to manipulate and abuse.
articles.abstract: Former students say military veterans who led J.R.O.T.C. classes in U.S. high schools fashioned themselves as mentors, then used their power to manipulate and abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: PICAYUNE, Miss. — With the rifle skills she honed in the Mississippi backwoods, Victoria Bauer had a path to escape the trap of drugs and dead-end jobs she saw most everywhere around her. Her future was in the Marines, she decided, and she had an idea about how to get there.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ilana Marcus and Mary F. Calvert

articles.headline: Fears of Another Gas Shock Drive Biden to Seek Price Cap on Russian Oil
articles.snippet: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.
articles.abstract: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Relief at the gas pump coupled with this past week’s news that businesses continue to hire at a blistering clip have tempered many economists’ fears that America is heading into a downturn.

articles.headline: Sri Lanka’s Leader Will Resign, Ally Says, After Protesters Storm Residence
articles.snippet: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
articles.abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage for the latest on Sri Lanka’s political crisis.
articles.byline: By Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: At 79, Biden Is Testing the Boundaries of Age and the Presidency
articles.snippet: President Biden has said he plans to run for a second term, but his age has become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party.
articles.abstract: President Biden has said he plans to run for a second term, but his age has become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Biden leaves Tuesday night for a four-day swing through the Middle East, he will presumably be more rested than he would have been had he followed the original plan.

articles.headline: Desperate for Recruits, Russia Launches a ‘Stealth Mobilization’
articles.snippet: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
articles.abstract: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four Russian veterans of the war in Ukraine recently published short videos online to complain about what they called their shabby treatment after returning to the Russian region of Chechnya, after six weeks on the battlefield.

articles.headline: One Small Step for Democracy in a ‘Live Free or Die’ Town
articles.snippet: A cautionary tale from Croydon, N.H., where one man tried to foist a change so drastic it jolted a community out of political indifference.
articles.abstract: A cautionary tale from Croydon, N.H., where one man tried to foist a change so drastic it jolted a community out of political indifference.
articles.lead_paragraph: CROYDON, N.H. — The tiny New Hampshire town of Croydon fits the New England of the imagination, with its cozy general store, one-room schoolhouse and local museum open by appointment. The only thing missing is supposed to be missing: a stoplight.

articles.headline: Inside a Uvalde Classroom: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
articles.snippet: A teacher who survived the mass shooting recounts the harrowing attack and desperate wait for a rescue.
articles.abstract: A teacher who survived the mass shooting recounts the harrowing attack and desperate wait for a rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — The first shots came from the hallway outside the classroom. Arnulfo Reyes, a fourth-grade teacher at Robb Elementary School, quickly remembered the active shooter training he had rehearsed so many times and told his 11 students to lie under their desks and “act like you are asleep.”

articles.headline: Airline Pilots Seek Big Raises, and Broader Changes
articles.snippet: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.
articles.abstract: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staffing shortages, bad weather, high fuel prices and runaway inflation — airlines face plenty of challenges as they seek to benefit from a strong travel rebound. But there’s at least one other complication in the mix: negotiating new pilot contracts.

articles.headline: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
articles.snippet: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
articles.abstract: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: To fight disinformation, California lawmakers are advancing a bill that would force social media companies to divulge their process for removing false, hateful or extremist material from their platforms. Texas lawmakers, by contrast, want to ban the largest of the companies — Facebook, Twitter and YouTube — from removing posts because of political points of view.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Defense Firm Said U.S. Spies Backed Its Bid for Pegasus Spyware Maker
articles.snippet: The American contractor L3Harris is said to have cited support from intelligence officials for its effort to acquire NSO, the Israeli spyware company blacklisted by the Biden administration.
articles.abstract: The American contractor L3Harris is said to have cited support from intelligence officials for its effort to acquire NSO, the Israeli spyware company blacklisted by the Biden administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: A team of executives from an American military contractor quietly visited Israel numerous times in recent months to try to carry out a bold but risky plan: purchasing NSO Group, the cyber hacking firm that is as notorious as it is technologically accomplished.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Cassidy Hutchinson: Why the Jan. 6 Committee Rushed Her Testimony
articles.snippet: Sequestered with family and security, Ms. Hutchinson, 26, has in the process developed an unlikely bond with Representative Liz Cheney, the panel’s vice chairwoman.
articles.abstract: Sequestered with family and security, Ms. Hutchinson, 26, has in the process developed an unlikely bond with Representative Liz Cheney, the panel’s vice chairwoman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before Cassidy Hutchinson was deposed for a fourth time by the Jan. 6 committee, the former Trump White House aide received a phone message that would dramatically change the plans of the panel and write a new chapter in American politics.

articles.headline: Inside the Amazon Journey That Left a Journalist and an Activist Dead
articles.snippet: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
articles.abstract: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

articles.headline: Most Democrats Don’t Want Biden in 2024, New Poll Shows
articles.snippet: With the country gripped by a pervasive sense of pessimism, the president is hemorrhaging support.
articles.abstract: With the country gripped by a pervasive sense of pessimism, the president is hemorrhaging support.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is facing an alarming level of doubt from inside his own party, with 64 percent of Democratic voters saying they would prefer a new standard-bearer in the 2024 presidential campaign, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, as voters nationwide have soured on his leadership, giving him a meager 33 percent job-approval rating.

articles.headline: In a Time of Conflict, Ukraine Entrepreneurs Make War Their Business
articles.snippet: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.
articles.abstract: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Yuriy Zakharchuk once dreamed up combat costumes for the stage, designing everything from medieval armor to space battle suits.

articles.headline: States With Abortion Bans Risk Losing Their Economic Edge
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a group of conservative states enacted severe abortion restrictions last year, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sent letters to a handful of corporate executives with close ties to Texas.

articles.headline: China’s Economy Stumbles in the Fog of Covid War
articles.snippet: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.
articles.abstract: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s economic engine has shuddered in recent months, hurt by lockdowns imposed to curb the spread of Covid. Housing sales sagged. Many shops and restaurants in some cities shuttered, some maybe for good. Youth unemployment climbed.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Alexandra Stevenson
